person.desc: American author of short science fiction whose work has appeared in the anthologies Again, Dangerous Visions and Cassandra Rising.
person.note: is a young writer who has also studied law and theater. This is her second appearance in QUARK/.

person.desc: British author of science fiction novels and stories.
person.note: most recent novels are The Jagged Orbit and Stand On Zanzibar, which won the Hugo Award as Best Science Fiction Novel of 1969.

person.desc: an American science fiction and horror writer sometimes associated with the Dangerous Visions series of anthologies that bolstered The New Wave.
person.note: has lived in Wyoming, Los Angeles, and New York. This is his second appearance in QUARK/.

person.desc: an American poet, publisher, photographer and filmmaker.
person.note: lives in New York. He has just completed his first film The Invasion of the Thunderbolt Pagoda, in collaboration with Bill Vehr.

person.desc: was an American science fiction writer and poet.
person.note: is the author of the novels The Genocides and Camp Concentration. He has also been widely published as a poet.

person.desc: Dorman published around two dozen science fiction short stories between 1961 and 1980, and she was associated with science fiction's "New Wave" of experimental writing.
person.note: fiction has appeared in Dangerous Visions and in Orbit; and her book, Poems, was published by Ohio University Press last fall.

person.desc: was an American writer of avant garde short stories and science fiction who has won prizes ranging from the Nebula Award to the Philip K. Dick Award. Ursula K. Le Guin has called her "a major fabulist, a marvelous magical realist, one of the strongest, most complex, most consistently feminist voices in fiction".
person.note: work is familiar to readers of Orbit and Dangerous Visions. She is presently completing her first novel.

person.desc: an American author known for his science fiction and fantasy novels and short stories.
person.note: is the author of the novels Flesh, The Lovers, and Blown, and of the novella Riders of the Purple Wage, which appeared in Dangerous Visions, and won a Hugo Award.
is a painter and a writer, whose art work appeared in QUARK/1. He lives in Vancouver. NEMI FROST is a San Francisco painter.

person.desc: an American poet, translator and critic. She is Professor of English emerita at the City College of New York.

person.note: is a linguist, a playwright, and a city planner. Several of his dramatic works have been produced in San Francisco.

person.desc: an American writer of fantasy, horror, and science fiction. He was also a poet, actor in theater and films, playwright, and chess expert.
person.note: received both the Hugo Award and the Nebula Award of the Science Fiction Writers of America for the story Gonna Roll Them Bones, which appeared in Dangerous Visions.
is Polish, born in Cairo, and educated in England. At present, he lives in Milford, Pennsylvania, where he is working on a novel.

person.desc: an American writer and science fiction critic.
person.note: is the author of the novels Masque World, The Thurb Revolution, and Rite Of Passage, which received the Nebula Award of the Science Fiction Writers of America.
is a painter who lives in San Diego.

person.desc: an American crime writer who wrote a series of novels featuring the detective character Lew Griffin
person.note: is a poet who lives in Milford, Pennsylvania. A collection of his short fiction, A Few Last Words, appeared last fall, and he is presently working on a book about American country music.

person.desc: was an American science fiction author
person.note: is the author of The Reproductive System, published in this country as Mechasm; and co-author, with Thomas M. Disch, of Black Alice. He is living in England.
is a young poet living in San Francisco.
story, The Selchey Kids, appeared in World's Best Science Fiction. He is a student at the University of California at Santa Cruz.
